comments.body:
I 100% support this idea, but for now, you can keep your constant scores organized. Fake player names can be a number, so you can have a scoreboard like this;

Constant Values Scoreboard Objective
0    0
1    1
3    3

and just reference each number.

I'm really in favor of this idea that the latter term can be a constant when using operator "*=", "/=" and "%=". Also, the syntax of the command should change a bit.

The original syntax is like this:

/scoreboard players operation <player: target> <targetObjective: string> <operation: operator> <selector: target> <objective: string>

And the new syntax should be either one below:

/scoreboard players operation <player: target> <targetObjective: string> (*=|/=|%=) player <selector: target> <objective: string>

/scoreboard players operation <player: target> <targetObjective: string> (*=|/=|%=) constant <number: float>
Please it's been five years
/gamerule randomTickSpeed 0 should disable ice from melting. However, it will also disable a few other things like crops growing and fire burning things.
Yeah, I agree with this. I'm trying to code custom weapons and it would be neat for things like daggers and spears to have vastly different reaches.
100% needed, please Mojang.
i would like this very much
Then what is the point of SNEAKING
The point on sneaking is so if your doing commands and you want to add Sneak detection you can easily do so. Before this you either had to no java or create a score board.

But the point of NBT data is for long-term storage. Why would it be relevant whether or not a player is sneaking if after they relog, they'll instantly unsneak?

Also, like you mentioned, you can just make a scoreboard objective and test for that. It's really not that difficult. If you're in 1.15 and above, you could even create a custom predicate in a datapack using the entity_properties condition that tests if a player is sneaking. There's no point in this new NBT tag.

"[If you wanted sneak detection] you either had to know Java or create a scoreboard"

Then create a freaking scoreboard it's not that hard.
It honestly just makes life easier mate.

384380991192 The point is to make it easier. Using a scoreboard requires multiple lines and is inelegant. Using a predicate requires creating a separate file. This all makes it more annoying to easily check if a player is sneaking.
you should also be able to control the commands they get to use.
I think this would be very helpful to minigame creators.
You could just use /spreadplayers for this
375600302911 Spreadplayers would only work with players, what about if you wanted to make a firestorm with randomly located fireballs?
Would be nice to use for summoning random lightning and such to create atmosphere, hope minecraft implements this or something similar

Or maybe make it a target selector, like maybe [lightlevel=""], and you could use dots to signify a continuation like in the scores selector: [lightlevel=""..], [lightlevel=""..""], or [lightlevel=..""]
Yeeeh! they added this today

And maybe @m to select every mob but not armor stands, items, arrows, etc. You would also have to name every single entity.
Or @g would only select passive mobs and @n could select neutral mobs.
You could just create tag files for this

Of course, the tag files would only work in Java Edition. Also, you could add a way to target entities that live in certain dimensions or habitats, or live in air, water, or land; or exist in real life, or are undead, etc.
Oh, and I forgot to mention that you couod also differenciate between living and non-living things. That would be very time-saving.
feedback @h mode hacker and mode Pro

for only hostiles, type @e[family=monster]

for only living, type @e[family=mob]

for only unliving, type @e[family=!mob]

the family selector exists on bedrock and works for what you want
Yes I love this and always wanted this

I hope it can seek out the different one even if a player stay at the same structure or biome.
For example, /locate(biome) xxx 1/2/3...

I think it would be a good idea to put the locate command also for the desert well, considering that it is the only structure that does not have this command (even abandoned mines have locate and generate dungeons more often).

This would be awesome for if you are modding a new ore or something and you want to see if it can generate in the world or if your world generation code failed. (sorry if it did :/) That way you wouldn't have to go around in spectator mode trying to find the ore that you made. Same thing with an entity.
Then u can make the player trackers!

I donâ€™t think you should think about replacing the "/setblock" command as many people have already relied on that command with command blocks for maps, but the other commands you suggested should be added to the game.
@mardymia You're right, I thought of that too, but maybe it would be better to have it all under 1 simple command.

This is very nearly perfect, but I'd recommend using `/setvolume` instead of `/set [shape]` where `[shape]` could be `cube`, `sphere`, `dome`, `cylinder`, pyramid, etc. So the command would be

`/setvolume <shape> <top-left-coordinate> <bottom-right-coordinate> <block type> [replace]`

for a 3x3x3 cube use a radius of 1, for example. The size of the structure would be determined by the volume provided by the coordinates given, generated truncated structures when the volume was unbalanced. In this way we could produce three-quarter domes using the `sphere` shape.

the option `[replace]` would accept either `true` or `false` and default to `false`; when the created structure would replace a non-air block the command would fail unless ``[replace]` equaled `true`.

Shouldn't you comment this on the /locate thread?

Edit wait no that thread is for biomes
It would also be nice if /rename could apply color codes to the new name of the item.

This is already possible using /data modify in Java Edition:

/data modify entity @s SelectedItem.tag.display.Name set value '{"text":"Test"}'

In Bedrock Edition, unfortunately, there isn't a fast way as a mapmaker to do this sort of stuff. You'll have to use an anvil instead.
/rename

As a (amateur) mapmaker myself, this would be very helpful, especially for chat based cooperative games. 

 

additionally, These rules should apply to people using /say, /msg, or /me
This is much needed right now.

This is not at all possible with how the game currently works, when you change NBT data, the game actually saves the entity, unloads it, changes the data, and loads it in again; this cannot be done for players at all.

And, before you ask, the NBT data != the internal variables.
This would be good for a werewolf adventure map.

/time is totally able to set the moon phase. Both the day-night cycle and moon phases are affected by the value of gametime, which can be changed with /time.

https://minecraft.gamepedia.com/Day-night_cycle#Moon_phases

I think it's more logical with a new /gamerule command for the time cycle speed. The idea is good, but it doesn't make sense if the day is longer than a night.
For example: / gamerule timecyclespeed [minutes in real life]

I love this idea and I'm working on a datapack for that :)

I think it's more usefull like that /particle <name> <x, y, z> <x2, y2, z2> <direction> <speed> <random motion> <count> [normal|force] [<viewers>] [<param>]

direction: direction where particle go (like the players head orientation), ~ ~ to keep the entity who execute the command head orientation.

random motion: motion aded to the particle, 0 to have the exacte direction.

param: color (for note particle for exemple) or block (for block particle)

This is already possible!

Just summon an area_effect_cloud and teleport it in a loop

summon area_effect_cloud
execute as @e[type=area_effect_cloud] at @s run teleport ~ ~ ~ <PerspectiveX> <Perspective>
execute as @e[type=area_effect_cloud] at @s run teleport ^ ^ ^0.2
execute as @e[type=area_effect_cloud] at @s run particle smoke ~ ~ ~ 0.1 0.1 0.1 0.2 20 normal

Now call this function 20 times per second.

Now you've got a raycast!
if you just want to make big trees: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rThzQsF3Mmc
protection 7, looting 5 rotten flesh is all i want for christmas
Yes! java have better commands
It works in Bedrock Edition too, it worked in Bedrock Edition since 1.16.
The bedrock one is missing many features and straight-up doesn't work. They should fix this. It would be so fun to mess with these.
You are able to obtain the block but the generate button does not exist.
YES PLEASE! This would make minigames and stuff with teams SO much easier! I hope this Idea Becomes BIG someday. :)

I would also love this for Bedrock Edition!!!! I want to be able to have two teams or more and turn team-friendly fire off so I can do a proper Capture the Flag Game!!!!!! Please add this to Minecraft!!!
This already exists in the form of an enchanted stick named "debug stick".

The problem is also that using /setblock or /fill to change the block state always resets all NBT tags of that block. This is for example a problem if you want to ignite a campfire because it deletes all items, that are being cooked. You can summon a small fireball instead in this case though. /blockstate would allow you to change block states while keeping NBT tags of the block.

This would be very helpful, recently I was working on a datapack for find the button, and to support resetting, the state of every button has to be remembered and then it compares the remembered data to call the correct /setblock command, this results in having 61 mcfunction files 1 file to check the type, 12 to check the facing and 48 to check the face. This is to optimize so that we aren't calling 144 commands at once instead it's only calling 19 commands at once.

Here are the two syntaxes I could think of being useful, the first being to set the state of one block, the block can be validate using execute so no need to include id or tag. The second one acts like the fill command and will modify an area, the id and tag are optional but if provided I'd imagine that it would only modify those that match the id or tag.

/state set <x> <y> <z> <state> <value>
/state fill <x> <y> <z> <dx> <dy> <dz> <state> <value> [id/tag]

The responses I imagine would be something along the lines of

/state set ~ ~ ~ waterlogged false
Error: "Could not modify the block"
Success: "Modified the block at 0, 0, 0"
/state fill ~ ~ ~ ~10 ~ ~20 waterlogged false #minecraft:stairs
Error: "No blocks were modified"
Success: "Successfully modified 2 blocks"

Another usefull thing would be:

/blockstate get <x> <y> <z> [state]

This returns the current blockstate of the block at position x y z. If the optional state parameter is provided, return only the value for that specific blockstate. Otherwise, return all blockstates (if any) of the block.

I have an idea for a similar kind of command, but instead of changing or retrieving a certain property of a block, I'd make it to save the entire block state, including name and properties into NBT and back with a syntax similar to this:

/blockstate (get|set) <x> <y> <z> (block ...|entity ...|storage ...) <path>

So if you wanted to alter a certain part of the block state, you'd do something like this:

/blockstate get ~ ~ ~ storage example:storage mystate
/data modify storage example:storage mystate facing set value "north"
/blockstate set ~ ~ ~ storage example:storage mystate

The added benefit would be to use this inside of falling blocks and block displays or the other way around:

/blockstate get ~ ~ ~ storage example:storage mystate
/execute align xyz summon block_display run data modify entity @s block_state set from storage example:storage mystate
/setblock ~ ~ ~ air

In this example, you replace a block with a block display of itself. A similar thing could be done for falling blocks.
That will be very hard to be used

I don't think Minecraft will add this.

However, for integer or float variables, you could use the scoreboard command, like this.

#Adds the scoreboard objective
scoreboard objectives add variable dummy

#Tells it about an un-existing player, and adds 1 to it's score
scoreboard players add example variable 1
Great idea!
Please add this !
Omg please add this

This is a highly requested feature but commands don't have the ability to "trace back" through the physical world to find who activated it. This has been requested many times before but I don't think it'll be coming soon. @p (nearest player) is the closest you'll get to that.

I know I'm really late, but..

There's an @initiator command that targets the player, but it only works with the NPC mob (Bedrock) So perhaps you could interact with a hidden npc that runs the command, but it's not a good solution.

The closest way we have to do what you require is by using @a along with scoreboards. For example, you can apply an effect to all players (@a) who have reached a specific score, like:

  /execute if entity @a[scores={objective1=1}] run effect give @a[scores={objective1=1}] minecraft:regeneration 5

and then reset their score after applying the desired effect with:

  /scoreboard players reset @a[scores={objective1=1}]

That's my proposal to achieve that. I'm sorry for commenting so late haha.
Imagine they add this but only for Java. I can see them doing that.
403768956532 I'm pretty sure this exists in java, with /execute. /execute in java has more arguments.

@EXDrill2522, there is a if condition in the execute command, but it doesn't seem to have else if and else callbacks.

Also, the execute command doesn't have while and for loops.

I just learned of another one called foreach. It is a shortener for for loops.

for(Object o : list) {/**Do stuff**/}

These are actually all possible in the Java Edition of Minecraft, there are loads of ways to create conditionals if you're willing to use scoreboards.

For the first one, we can set up a scoreboard and run the following commands in order:

execute store result score FakePlayer myObjective if entity @s[tag=pizza] run summon minecraft:cat
execute if score FakePlayer myObjective matches 0 store result score FakePlayer myObjective if entity @s[tag=burger] run summon minecraft:wolf
execute if score FakePlayer myObjective matches 0 run summon parrot

For the second one, we set a redstone block next to a repeating command chain with the message, followed by a chain command block that removes the redstone block if the required entity is not detected:

execute if entity @a[tag=some] run say This is annoying!
execute unless entity @a[tag=some] run setblock 12 23 34 minecraft:air

And for the third one, we can increment a scoreboard value by 1 every time a command is run, and stop the entire command chain when the score is 10.

In Bedrock Edition, I would advocate for getting the /stats command added to Bedrock Edition instead, to let the storage of command results to scores.
This would open up much more possibilities and make it easier. I really don't want to mess with tons of command blocks.
